prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal G11
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 Polarization in 4 cores in G11

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We propose to observe 1.3mm (Band 6) continuum emission in all four basebands in the default polarization mode offered for Band 6. This will ensure maximum sensivitity to weak polarized signal.

Since off-axis polarization has not been tested with ALMA, only those cores that are very compact (< 1/3 of the primary beam of 24") have been chosen. In order to well resolve the cores and have enough independent resolution elements for statistical analysis of the polarization vectors, we choose 2'' beam for G11. The cores sizes are smaller than the maximum recoverable scale of ~11".

Our aim is to achieve a continuum sensitivity of 0.044 mJy per 2" beam. This is based on SMA & PdBI(G11) flux density at the same frequency and similar beam size. Hence the flux density and extent of the cores are known.
In order to resolve the cores and have enough independent resolution elements for statistical analysis of the polarization vectors, we choose beam sizes of ~1.5" for G0.253 and 2" for G11. The core sizes are smaller than the maximum recoverable scale of ~11". Our SD measurements detect polarized flux at 3 -5% level in these clouds and if we assume a similar degree of polarization (3%) at sub-pc scale. Using the average (not peak) flux from our SMA & PdBI data and scaling it to the requested beamsize, we estimate that the signal is polarized at 3% level corresponding to a 5\,$\sigma$ sensitivity of 0.044 mJy for a 2" beam for G11.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal G0.253
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 Polarization in 15 cores in G0.253

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We propose to observe 1.3mm (Band 6) continuum emission in all four basebands in the default polarization mode offered for Band 6. This will ensure maximum sensivitity to weak polarized signal.

Since off-axis polarization has not been tested with ALMA, only those cores that are very compact (<1/3 of the primary beam of 24") have been chosen. In order to well resolve the cores and have enough independent resolution elements for statistical analysis of the polarization vectors, we choose ~1.5" beam for G0.253. The cores sizes are smaller than the maximum recoverable scale of 11".

Our aim is to achieve a continuum sensitivity of 0.04 mJy per 1.5" beam. This is based on ALMA flux density at the same frequency and similar beam size. Hence the flux density and extent of the cores are known. For G0.253, not all significant ALMA peaks were selected. The best compromise between reasonable observing time and spatial coverage of the key strcutures that dilineate the large filament led us to choose 15 dense cores.
In order to resolve the cores and have enough independent resolution elements for statistical analysis of the polarization vectors, we choose 1.5" for G0.253. The core widths are smaller than the maximum recoverable scale of ~11". Our SD measurements detect polarized flux at 3 -5% level in these clouds and if we assume a similar degree of polarization (3%) at sub-pc scale. Using the average (not peak) flux from our ALMA data and scaling it to the requested beamsize, we estimate that the signal is polarized at 3% level corresponding to a 5\,$\sigma$ sensitivity of 0.04 mJy for a 1.5" beam for G0.253.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: High-mass Stars are cosmic engines known to dominate the energetics in galaxies. However, their formation is still not well understood. Massive, cold, dense clouds, often appearing as Infrared Dark Clouds (IRDCs), are massive stellar nurseries. No measurements of magnetic fields in IRDCs in a state prior to the onset of high-mass star formation (HMSF) have been available until very recently. Only studies of early stages can constrain the initial conditions for HMSF. We now reported observations of magnetic fields in two of the most massive IRDCs. We show that G11.11-0.12 and G0.253+0.016 are strongly magnetized. This shows for the first time that magnetic field is as important as turbulence and gravity for HMSF. We now propose to study the field on sub-parsec scales where the gas fragments into cores that form stars. To do so we pick starless cores within these unique unperturbed IRDCs. The interpretation of observations is supported by extensive custom--made numerical simulations of magnetized clouds. Combined with polarization data on larger scales, these observations will provide the first panoramic view of the magnetized nature and thus initial conditions of HMSF.
